subtitles.transcript: Generally it’s hard to have a free tuition model where you also provide resources for those non-tuition costs, right?
Because the state has to choose what to subsidize. It can subsidize tuition for everyone or it can
subsidize tuition plus then some for some, right? And that latter one is arguably a lot more progressive, right?
Because you’re really targeting the resources you have on the people who can’t pay
and you are expecting more from the people who can afford more. Scotland, I believe, has a free college model,
but they’ve recently gotten rid of all their grants for non-tuition costs and said
if students want to have money for non-tuition costs, they can take it out in a loan.
That’s not progressive. It might be free tuition, but it’s not progressive.
